title: Bus passenger fined £476 after phone dies and she can't prove she paid £1.50 fare
text:

A bus passenger was fined almost £500 after her iPhone died, leaving her unable to prove she had paid the £1.50 fare.

A conductor asked Jemima Kelly for her ticket five minutes after she boarded the London bus, however, she could not provide it as her iPhone had run out of battery.

The blogger, who had tapped onto the vehicle with Apple Pay, gave the official her details and thought nothing more of the episode.

A couple of months later she received a letter from Transport for London (TfL), warning her she had 21 days to either plead guilty or not guilty to failing to produce a ticket.

(Image: PA)

She sent a bank statement to TfL proving she had paid the fare, however this was considered insufficient evidence.

In April, Ms Kelly was shocked to discover that £476.50 had been taken out of her pay cheque, following a court request.

Her conviction also resulted in the cancellation of a 'bleisure' trip to America after a US embassy official refused to give her a visa.

This left her £1,000 out of pocket as she could not afford to rebook her flights, which were non-refundable.

Her conviction was later quashed at a subsequent hearing but the writer still feels frustrated about the experience.

She wrote in the Financial Times : "I always thought that criminals were meant to be the ones that exploited 'innovation'.

"But it felt like innovation had exploited me, and turned me into a criminal. I still use Apple Pay to tap in on buses and trains — I’m not going to seek revenge against the digital revolution just because it stung me.

"But I have now invested in a portable charger. I must stop forgetting to charge it."
description: Blogger Jemima Kelly's upcoming trip to the US was cancelled because she couldn't get a visa following her fare dodging conviction
